question: [File: ecosystem/indexer-grpc/indexer-grpc-table-info/src/internal_indexer_db_service.rs] [Function: new()] [Race condition] Can concurrent calls to new() with the same db_reader and internal_indexer_db create multiple DBIndexer instances that process the same data concurrently, leading to duplicate writes and database corruption? (High)

[File: ecosystem/indexer-grpc/indexer-grpc-table-info/src/internal_indexer_db_service.rs] [Function: new()] [State inconsistency] If the update_receiver is already consumed or closed when passed to new(), can this cause the service to start with stale version information, leading to missed transactions or indexing gaps? (Medium)

[File: ecosystem/indexer-grpc/indexer-grpc-table-info/src/internal_indexer_db_service.rs] [Function: new()] [Resource exhaustion] Does the Arc<DBIndexer> wrapper prevent proper cleanup of underlying database resources, potentially causing file descriptor leaks or memory exhaustion when services are repeatedly created and destroyed? (Medium)

[File: ecosystem/indexer-grpc/indexer-grpc-table-info/src/internal_indexer_db_service.rs] [Function: get_indexer_db_for_restore()] [Panic vulnerability] Can a malicious actor provide a db_dir path that doesn't exist or lacks permissions, causing the expect() call to panic and crash the entire indexer service? (High)

[File: ecosystem/indexer-grpc/indexer-grpc-table-info/src/internal_indexer_db_service.rs] [Function: get_indexer_db_for_restore()] [Path traversal] Can an attacker manipulate the db_dir parameter to use path traversal sequences (../) to access or corrupt database files outside the intended directory structure? (Critical)

[File: ecosystem/indexer-grpc/indexer-grpc-table-info/src/internal_indexer_db_service.rs] [Function: get_indexer_db_for_restore()] [Configuration injection] Does the function use NodeConfig::default() without validation, allowing an attacker who controls default configuration to inject malicious rocksdb_config parameters that compromise database integrity? (High)

[File: ecosystem/indexer-grpc/indexer-grpc-table-info/src/internal_indexer_db_service.rs] [Function: get_indexer_db_for_restore()] [Hardcoded configuration vulnerability] Are the hardcoded InternalIndexerDBConfig values (true, true, true, 0, true, 10_000) secure defaults, or can enabling all features simultaneously create unexpected interactions that corrupt indexed data? (Medium)

[File: ecosystem/indexer-grpc/indexer-grpc-table-info/src/internal_indexer_db_service.rs] [Function: get_indexer_db_for_restore()] [Race condition] If multiple processes attempt to restore from the same db_dir concurrently, can this cause database lock conflicts or corruption due to competing RocksDB instances? (High)

[File: ecosystem/indexer-grpc/indexer-grpc-table-info/src/internal_indexer_db_service.rs] [Function: get_indexer_db_for_restore()] [Return type vulnerability] Does returning Some(InternalIndexerDB) without validating database integrity mean corrupted databases could be loaded, causing subsequent indexing operations to propagate corruption? (Medium)

[File: ecosystem/indexer-grpc/indexer-grpc-table-info/src/internal_indexer_db_service.rs] [Function: get_indexer_db()] [Silent failure] If is_internal_indexer_db_enabled() returns false, the function returns None without any logging or notification - can this hide critical indexer initialization failures that break downstream query services? (Medium)

[File: ecosystem/indexer-grpc/indexer-grpc-table-info/src/internal_indexer_db_service.rs] [Function: get_indexer_db()] [Panic vulnerability] Can a corrupted or malicious node_config with invalid storage paths cause the expect() call to panic, taking down the entire node without graceful degradation? (High)

[File: ecosystem/indexer-grpc/indexer-grpc-table-info/src/internal_indexer_db_service.rs] [Function: get_indexer_db()] [Configuration tampering] If an attacker modifies node_config.indexer_db_config between the is_enabled check and InternalIndexerDB::new() call, can this create a database with mismatched configuration leading to data corruption? (High)

[File: ecosystem/indexer-grpc/indexer-grpc-table-info/src/internal_indexer_db_service.rs] [Function: get_indexer_db()] [Path injection] Does get_dir_paths().default_root_path() properly validate the path to prevent symlink attacks or directory traversal that could expose sensitive database files? (High)

[File: ecosystem/indexer-grpc/indexer-grpc-table-info/src/internal_indexer_db_service.rs] [Function: get_indexer_db()] [Resource leak] If open_internal_indexer_db() succeeds but InternalIndexerDB::new() fails, is the Arc<DB> properly cleaned up, or does this leave open file handles and locked database files? (Medium)

[File: ecosystem/indexer-grpc/indexer-grpc-table-info/src/internal_indexer_db_service.rs] [Function: get_start_version()] [Integer overflow] Can an attacker cause main_db_synced_version to overflow when adding 1 to compute start_version, potentially causing version wraparound that skips critical transactions? (Critical)

[File: ecosystem/indexer-grpc/indexer-grpc-table-info/src/internal_indexer_db_service.rs] [Function: get_start_version()] [Infinite loop] During fast sync, if ensure_synced_version() persistently returns 0 due to a bug or attack, does the while loop at line 97-100 run forever, causing a DoS by consuming CPU resources indefinitely? (High)

[File: ecosystem/indexer-grpc/indexer-grpc-table-info/src/internal_indexer_db_service.rs] [Function: get_start_version()] [Time-of-check to time-of-use] Between checking fast_sync_enabled and reading main_db_synced_version, can the fast sync complete and the state change, causing race conditions in version determination? (Medium)

[File: ecosystem/indexer-grpc/indexer-grpc-table-info/src/internal_indexer_db_service.rs] [Function: get_start_version()] [Version desynchronization] If get_persisted_version() returns None but different indexer types (statekeys, transaction, event) have different versions, can this create inconsistent start_version across indexer components? (High)

[File: ecosystem/indexer-grpc/indexer-grpc-table-info/src/internal_indexer_db_service.rs] [Function: get_start_version()] [Panic vulnerability - statekeys] If enable_statekeys() is true but start_version != state_start_version, the panic at line 115 crashes the entire service - can an attacker corrupt state_version to intentionally trigger this panic and DoS the indexer? (High)

[File: ecosystem/indexer-grpc/indexer-grpc-table-info/src/internal_indexer_db_service.rs] [Function: get_start_version()] [Panic vulnerability - transaction] If enable_transaction() is true but start_version != transaction_start_version, the panic at line 126 provides no recovery mechanism - can partial database restoration cause permanent service failure? (High)

[File: ecosystem/indexer-grpc/indexer-grpc-table-info/src/internal_indexer_db_service.rs] [Function: get_start_version()] [Panic vulnerability - event] If enable_event() is true but start_version != event_start_version, the panic at line 137 prevents service startup - can disk corruption in event indexes cause unrecoverable node failure? (High)

[File: ecosystem/indexer-grpc/indexer-grpc-table-info/src/internal_indexer_db_service.rs] [Function: get_start_version()] [Complex conditional bypass] Can an attacker manipulate event_v2_translation_ignores_below_version() to be >= start_version to bypass the version consistency check at lines 147-158, allowing desynchronized event v2 translation? (Medium)

[File: ecosystem/indexer-grpc/indexer-grpc-table-info/src/internal_indexer_db_service.rs] [Function: get_start_version()] [Panic vulnerability - event v2] The panic at line 153-157 includes both start_version and event_v2_translation_start_version in the error message - can this information leak be exploited to determine internal state for targeted attacks? (Low)

[File: ecosystem/indexer-grpc/indexer-grpc-table-info/src/internal_indexer_db_service.rs] [Function: get_start_version()] [Dependency vulnerability] The panic at line 160 triggers when event v2 translation is enabled but event indexer is not - can an attacker modify node_config flags to create this inconsistent state and crash the service? (Medium)

[File: ecosystem/indexer-grpc/indexer-grpc-table-info/src/internal_indexer_db_service.rs] [Function: get_start_version()] [Async safety] Is get_start_version() safe to call concurrently from multiple async contexts, or can parallel calls lead to inconsistent version reads due to non-atomic operations on the database? (High)
